name: Clean Electricity
text: Switzerland's electricity production has one of the lowest carbon intensity in the world. Only 3% is from fossil fuels. Therefore most people consume clean electricity by default. If all electricity in Switzerland was clean, annual emissions would be {impact} megaton lower.
progress_text: {progress}% of energy produced in Switzerland is clean.
button_text: I consume only clean electricity

name: Renewable Electricity
text: The difference between clean energy and renewable energy is that nuclear energy is considered clean but not renewable. This because GHG emissions from nuclear energy are minimal. Howevery, nuclear energy is finite i.e. not renewable. In terms of GHG emissions clean and renewable energy have the same impact. If all electricity in Switzerland was renewable, annual emissions would be {impact} megaton lower.
progress_text: {progress}% of energy produced in Switzerland is renewable.
button_text: I consume only renewable elecricity

name: Solar Pannels
text: Even though almost all electricity produced in Switzerland is clean, the country imports some electricity from its neighbours. In 2021 there was a 4% net-import of electricity. The more people are willing to install solar pannels on their rooftop, the more electricity can ber produced within Switzerland and without carbon emissions. If twice as many people had solar panels on their rooftops, we could reduce imported emissions by another megation.

name: No Beef & Diary
text:
If everybody in Switzerland stopped eating beef and diary products, annual emissions would be {impact} megatons lower.

This is because cows are very bad for the climate because:

1) When cows digest grass they emmit methane, a greenhouse gas that is 25 times more potent than carbondioxide.

2) Cows produce large quantities of manure, which releases methane and nitrous oxide as it decomposes.

3) Cows requires large areas of land. This often leads to deforestation, which not only releases the carbon stored in trees but also reduces the planet's capacity to absorb CO2 from the atmosphere.

4)  Cows require significant amounts of water and feed, which in order to produce, process and transport contributes substantially to CO2 emissions.

If you stop eating cow products, you can significantly reduce emissions. In fact, eating no cow products has a bigger impact than being a vegetarian (who eats diary products).
progress_text: Currently the number of people in Switzerland who do not eating beef and diary products is not tracke.

name: Buy Local
text: There is no other country in ther world that has as much imported emissions as Switzerland. Buying local would reduce emissions. However, most products such as cars are not produced in Switzerland but only abroad. Therefore buying local would only reduce {impact] megatons of emissions
progress_text: {progress}% of people in Switzerland prefer prefer local agricultural products.
button_text: I only buy local agricultural products.

name: Reduce & Reuse
text: Another way to reduce emissions is to reduce consumption, repairing and buying second hand products. If everybody bought second hand cloth instead of buying new cloth, Switzerland's annual emissions would be reduced by {impact} megatons.
progress_text: {progress}% of people in Switzerland have bought second-hand cloth in the last year.
button_text: I try to buy second-hand items whenever possible

name: Offset Consumption
text: Carbon offsetting has received some bad press in recent years because there have been many fraudulent offseting companies. However, offsetting emissions can make a huge difference if you chose a trustworthy provider. In Switzerland myClimate is a trustworthy provider. The biggest problem with offsetting is that you pay for projects that prevent more GHG to go into the atmosphere, not to remove it. So you do not really offset your emissions. You just pay to make things worse by preventing others to emit. Usually caron is offset in a developing countries because smaller investments have a higher impact. If everybody offst their emissions we could reduce imported emissions by {impact} megatons
progress_text: The number of people who offset emissions is not tracket in Switzerland

name: Boycott Climate Offenders
text: The organisation Climate Action 100+ has identified 170 companies that are key in driving the worlds GHG emissions to zero. If these companies reduced emissions to zero, we could cut industry emissions in half. However, only 17% of them have the goal to do so. If all of them did, Switzerland's annual emissions would be {impact} megatons lower.
progress_text: {progress}% of companies monitored by Climate Action 100+ have net-zero targets
button_text: I boycott companies with a bad climate rating

name: Buy only climate-friendly
text: Even though there are almost no climate-neutral companies in Switzerland (and the world) yet. Almost half of G20 companies in terms of revenue have joined the "race to zero" initiatives and pledged to half their emissions by 2030. If these companies really halved their emissions, Switzerland's annual emissions would be {impact} lower.
progress_text: {progress}% of companies joined the race to zero initiative.
button_text: I only buy from climate-friendly companies

name: Buy only climate-neutral
text: Swiss companies are responsible for almost half of Switzerland's emissions. If all Swiss companies were climate-neutral, we could reduce annual emissions by {impact} megatons per year. Unfortunately only very few are climate-neutral. In fact most don't even report their emissions. If all companies in Switzerland were climate-neutral, annual emissions would be {impact} lower.
progress_text: {progress}% of large companies report GHG emissions
button_text: I only buy from climate-neutral companies

name: Follow Innovation
text: If we want to reach net-zero, innovation will contribute significantly to achieving this goal. Thanks to innvoation, solar energy is today not only a source of cean and renewable energy, it is also the cheapest source of energy. Other inventions such as hydrogen fuel, direct air capture or advanced batteries all have the potential to substantially boost the green transition. It is important to support innovation, even if it is just by following it.

name: No (Fossil) Investments
text: Switzerland's emissions are only 0.1% of global emissions. However, McKinsey estimates that Switzerland as a financial center is indirectly responsible for 2 - 3% of global emissions. Most people are unaware that their investments can have a huge indirect impact on emissions. For example, there are zero coal power plants in Switzerland. However, 80% of banks and asset managers in Switzerland invest in coal power plants in other countries.

text: Switzerland's ecosystem (mostly forests) remove 2 megatons of emissions every year. It is therefore important to keep these ecosystems protected.
